awd_titl_txt: Identification of Urban Flood Impacts Caused by Land Subsidence and Sea Level Rise for the Houston-Galveston Region
awd_abstract_narration:
In addition to being vulnerable to natural hazards such as hurricanes or tropical storms, many coastal cities also experience significant land subsidence and sea level rise which can exacerbate the urban floods. Although many previous studies have started to realize the significant impacts imposed by land subsidence and sea level rise to coastal communities, incorporating these factors into flood inundation modeling and planning is still a challenge. To address this challenge, this project develops a model to understand and identify the contributing impacts from land subsidence and sea level rise to urban floods. The model will be tested on the Houston-Galveston region using selected extreme events including Hurricane Harvey which occurred in 2017. The goal of the project is to improve U.S. urban flood mitigation and strategic planning to save lives and protect properties from damage and to increase urban sustainability and resilience. 

The goal of the proposed research is to understand and identify urban flood exacerbated by the contributing impacts from land subsidence and sea level rise. The enhanced hydrologic and hydraulic models will be coupled with a developed land subsidence simulation model and one sea level rise projection model downscaled to the San Jacinto River Basin to identify corresponding flood impacts contributed by land subsidence and sea level rise for the Houston-Galveston region. The proposed methodology assimilates land subsidence and sea level rise scenarios into hydrologic and hydraulic modeling to delineate inundation extents. This method takes advantage of a processed-based distributed hydrologic model to reveal the underpinning of the urban flood exacerbated by land subsidence and sea level rise. The Houston-Galveston region is selected as the test-bed for the proposed project, a historical land subsidence zone that has subsided up to 10 ft. since 1940s and where sea level rise is projected to rise another 1 to 4 ft. by 2100. The research results will advance current knowledge on interactions among atmospheric, hydrological and geological systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Coastal cities face the dual challenge of natural hazards and the persistent threat of land subsidence and sea level rise. While previous studies have recognized the significant impacts of these phenomena on coastal communities, incorporating them into flood modeling and planning remains a formidable task. This project aims to bridge this gap by developing a comprehensive model to assess the contributions of land subsidence and sea level rise to urban floods. By focusing on extreme events, such as Hurricane Harvey in 2017, we seek to enhance flood mitigation and strategic planning, thereby safeguarding lives and properties and fostering urban sustainability and resilience.

The 2017 Hurricane Harvey, a devastating tropical storm, inundated Houston, Texas, raising questions about the role of land subsidence besides enormous rainfall amount in exacerbating the flood. This study investigates 117 years (1900 to 2017) of land subsidence using the Houston Area Groundwater Model (HAGM) and its impact on flood inundation, particularly in Brays Bayou, Texas. The results reveal a relatively minor overall change in flood depth, with a six-centimeter deepening per one meter of subsided land at the most affected location. Notably, the study highlights the nonlinearity of the impact over time, indicating that earlier land subsidence hotspots can be altered by subsequent subsidence. Spatially, the changes in flood depth are heterogeneous, with coexisting increased and reduced flood depths. These findings contribute to a better understanding of the dynamic evolution of flood inundation, crucial for sustainable urban development in the face of ongoing urbanization, climate change and sea level rise.

Examining the relative sea level rise at Galveston Pier 21, Texas, we consider the combined effects of absolute sea level rise and land subsidence. Aquifer-system compaction, associated with groundwater extraction, contributes up to 85% of the 0.7 meters relative sea level rise since 1909, with an additional 1.9 meters projected by 2100. Importantly, this study suggests that the extreme scenario evaluation is crucial for resource management and flood hazard mitigation, particularly in the Gulf of Mexico. Moreover, it reveals the impact of creep compaction on land subsidence, emphasizing its significance in the context of relative sea level rise.

This project also evaluates groundwater level change management's role in controlling land subsidence, supported by borehole extensometer compaction measurements from 1979 to 2017 in the Houston-Galveston Region, Texas. The findings not only validate the efficacy of groundwater level change management but also provide empirical evidence of above-creep subsidence in the Quaternary and Tertiary aquifer systems, emphasizing the need to consider creep compaction in relative sea level rise assessments.

The impact of this research extends beyond scientific contributions, with a total of 16 journal articles, 2 dissertations, and 1 book chapter produced. The research teams from Morgan State University (MSU) and the University of Texas at Arlington (UTA) presented their findings in 30 oral or poster presentations at international, national, regional, and local conferences, reaching diverse audiences. While 18 K-12 students in Baltimore learned about sea level rise and land subsidence, more than 750 undergraduates and graduates from both institutions directly benefited from the integration of research results into civil and environmental engineering courses. Additionally, field training provided valuable hands-on experience to 6 UTA students as well as 4 MSU students in flooding, sea level rise, and land subsidence.

The synergetic research efforts make theoretical, interdisciplinary, technical, and practical contributions that altogether improve the sustainability, resilience, livability, and general wellbeing of communities in coastal cities. This project enhanced multi-university collaborations among the University of Texas at Arlington (UTA) and Morgan State University (MSU) through collaborative efforts in developing a multi-modeling framework for long-term hazard mitigation plannings. Not only did these efforts lead to direct collaboration within the universities but also with the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers – Fort Worth District, U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), the Severe Storm Prediction, Education, and Evacuation from Disasters (SSPEED) Center, and National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) during the project period from 2018 to 2023. The project serves as a solid foundation for further enhancements for addressing the needs of understanding of urban flood resilience and multi-disciplinary modeling research, and further enables the multi-institutional participations in activities involving collaborative research and science education.

In summary, this project enhances the understanding of urban flood impacts in the Houston-Galveston region by integrating land subsidence, urbanization, and sea level rise into flood modeling. The multifaceted approach not only improves flood mitigation and planning strategies but also contributes valuable knowledge to the broader scientific community and educates the next generation of engineers and researchers.
